reviewText:
The best parody from Symphony of the Night ever made!

You have two character options right away, each one have a different storyline, set of items and skills to learn, which adds a bit of replay value.
Unlike Castlevania, no matter what character you start, you will need to upgrade him to advance further.
Most enemies lacks a bit of agressiveness and only follow the same pattern, but some bosses caught me at surprise.
At first it was easy to advance in the game, but later it took me some time to figure out where I should go next, the map is fun to laught at, but doesn't help in anything and there is no guide anywhere on internet.
The items are in the same place, if they were in different locations for each character, it would be better. However, the way each character needs to get those items worth the trouble of playing it again.

I laughed a lot with this game, it's really confusing sometimes, but I recommend it.

7/10

reviewText: Firstly I'd just like to say that this is a Recommended with hesitation"\n\nI have a mixed bag of feelings for this game.  It's a game that I feel would have felt right at home in my DOS collection in the years of the early Duke Nukem games and games of the like
date: by today's standards it just feels a tad lacking
recommended: but in an odd sense that's not entirely negative.\n\nPicture if someone from the mid to late 80's travelled in a time machine to modern day and saw games like Castlevania: Sympthony of the Night or other Metroidvanias
hoursPlayed: and decided to take that knowledge back with them and used the technology they had to work with in the late 80's.  I'd almost put this game in between a cozy place of Metroid and Legacy of the Wizard for NES; but a heavy C:SotN vibe.  Is it beautiful?  no.  Is the music stellar?  hardly.  But it still has a slight retro charm to it
voteText: whether it be intentional or not.\n\nThe game gives two characters to play
helpfulPercent: I've only played as the ninja
votesHelpful: and it's pretty straight forward.  You get a ranged attack
votesFunny: backdash and jump.  You find powerups and spells later on which help you progress further in the game.  The combat is really straight forward
commentsCount: later bosses you will have to learn their attack patterns at times to avoid certain death
column16: but aside from that the combat is simplistic.\n\nI can't rightly not recommend this game since it's not broken or dreadful albeit a little bland at times
column17: yet giving it a thumbs up I do so with hesitation.  Another game where a thumbs in the middle would be appropriate
column18: since I think there are far more games in this genre I'd sing the praises of first.  I got this game in a bundle so the price isn't hugely a deciding factor for me
column19: but for anyone purchasing at the full retail price I may suggest waiting for a sale or it to appear in a bundle
column20: that aside though I think there is still some enjoyment to be had from this game regardless
column21: I just feel $5-$7 would be a more appealing price to the consumer for having them feel like they got their money's worth
column22: due to just how saturated the market is with this genre of games that are competitively priced."
